channel.title: New to this
channel.description: So I've been here before, but I got annoyed and left because I didn't understand anything about it. All I knew how to do was leech and host servers. So I was wondering what types of coding go into making an actual runescape server. I'm interested in the (317) style ones. Specifically I want to know ALL types of coding used in making your own server, and ALL types of coding used in making your own client. TYIA :P

item.title: New to this
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

[quote=“Manual Clutch, post:6, topic:431257”][quote author=lemme_winks_ link=topic=533934.msg3903252#msg3903252 date=1327963976]

you can use any multi-purpose language really…it depends on what you are most comfortable with. a lot of servers are written in java, especially the good ones, so if you like java, and you wish to learn more about how others have written them, it might be a good idea to use hyperion, rs2dev, or apollo as for a reference.

java might be a good idea for someone like you to use. they have bulit-in networking APIs which makes it considerably easier for newbies to use, compared to downloading and using a third-party library. if you were to use c/++, you would have to depend on a library like ASIO, SDL Net, or Ace.

for java references and code docs, you might want to look around the internet.

Thanks for the reply. But I was wondering, do you have to use a different coding when making a client? Like when you start a client for the .cmd to run everything?

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/windows/java.html

example:

java -cp <class-path> <main-class>

i wouldn’t advise anybody to rewrite a game client for runescape because that would be highly unnecessary and re-inventing the wheel to a max. not to mention you having to deal with unprofessionally tested code, restructuring and planning new architecture–issues alike that jagex already dealt with over the years.
[/quote]
How do people customize a client to go along with their own server then?[/quote]

it is called modifying open-source code

Read full topic

item.title: New to this
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

you can use any multi-purpose language really…it depends on what you are most comfortable with. a lot of servers are written in java, especially the good ones, so if you like java, and you wish to learn more about how others have written them, it might be a good idea to use hyperion, rs2dev, or apollo as for a reference.

java might be a good idea for someone like you to use. they have bulit-in networking APIs which makes it considerably easier for newbies to use, compared to downloading and using a third-party library. if you were to use c/++, you would have to depend on a library like ASIO, SDL Net, or Ace (not mentioning other dependencies).

for java references and code docs, you might want to look around the internet.

Read full topic
